squeeze.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to press something firmly together with your fingers or hand
squeeze.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: She smiled as he squeezed her hand.
He squeezed the trigger, but nothing happened.
squeeze.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to get liquid from something by pressing it
squeeze.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: Try to squeeze a bit more out.
Squeeze a bit of lemon juice onto the fish.
squeeze.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to try to make something fit into a space that is too small, or to try to get into such a space
squeeze.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: Five of us squeezed into the back seat.
He had squeezed through a gap in the fence.
We could probably squeeze in a few more people.
squeeze.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to succeed, win, or pass a test by a very small amount so that you only just avoid failure
squeeze.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: Greece just squeezed through into the next round.
squeeze.translation[0].definitions[4].de: to strictly limit the amount of money that is available to a company or organization
squeeze.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: The government is squeezing the railwaysâ€™ investment budget.
squeeze.translation[1].definitions[0].de: an act of pressing something firmly with your fingers or hand
squeeze.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: Marty gave her hand a little squeeze.
squeeze.translation[1].definitions[1].de: a situation in which wages, prices, borrowing money etc are strictly controlled or reduced
squeeze.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: All manufacturers are feeling the squeeze  (=noticing the effects of a difficult financial situation).
cuts due to the squeeze on public sector spending
squeeze.translation[2].definitions[0].de: to strictly limit the amount of money that is available to a company or organization
squeeze.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: Health care spending is being squeezed.
The firm says that its profit margin is gettingsqueezed by rising costs for its primary raw material.
squeeze.translation[2].definitions[1].de: to get the most you possibly can from something
squeeze.translation[2].definitions[1].ex: Johnson was known to squeeze every dollar out of every contract.
Company managers can squeeze more from their capital assets if they choose markets carefully and set clearer goals.
squeeze.translation[3].definitions[0].de: a situation in which wages, prices, borrowing money etc are strictly limited, especially by a government in order to control inflation
squeeze.translation[3].definitions[0].ex: The union is protesting against the 1.5% pay squeeze.
